Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: The grandfather notices his grandchild seems to be feeling lost or discouraged about a personal matter.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: On the final day of the quarter, the team must hit the cumulative target to avoid penalties and secure bonuses.
Story: I sat at my cluttered kitchen table, headset on, fingers drumming nervously as I watched the clock tick toward the end of the quarter. My sales manager’s voice echoed in my mind—“We need five more sign-ups, or we all lose the bonus.” The pressure was suffocating. Just then, my grandson shuffled into the room, eyes downcast, shoulders slumped. I could tell something was weighing on him, something more important than any sales call. As a grandfather, I knew I should set aside my work, offer him a seat, and listen—share some of the hard-earned wisdom I’d gathered over the years. But the phone lines were lighting up, and every second I hesitated meant another missed opportunity, another step closer to letting my team down. My heart ached as I looked from my grandson to the blinking screen, torn between the demands of my job and the needs of my family, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
